segments.text: We're back with another edition of the Federalist Radio Hour.
I'm Emily Jaczenski, Culture Editor here at The Federalist.
As always, you can email the show at radio at thefederalist.com.
Follow us on Twitter at FDRLST.
Make sure to subscribe wherever you download your podcasts as well.
Today I'm coming to you from Wisconsin with a special edition of the Federalist Radio Hour.
As we close out the year, we want to share something with our loyal and wonderful listeners
that we're most proud of.
One of the things we are most proud of from our coverage this year, we've always been
very proud of our coverage of schools, of our education system, of parents, and their
work to defend their children, protect their children, and to improve their experience
in the schools.
This year, in particular, things were sort of boiling, hitting a boiling point in Loudon
County, which is about an hour, a little less than an hour outside of Washington, DC.
We produced a full-length documentary called Meet the Parents, How the Moms and Dads of
Loudon County Took Back Virginia that was filmed in the weeks that were leading up to
Glen Yunken's surprising victory in Loudon County or in the state of Virginia, I should
say.
And it was something that was very surprising to people in the Beltway.
We talked about it at length here, despite the fact that Virginia is really in their
backyard is the state that they've turned blue in their backyard.
They really didn't see what was happening, and they still refused to see what is happening,
although some sort of establishment Democrats seem to be waking up.
But this documentary we want to share with our podcast listeners, we're going to play
the full audio of it because the parents are remarkable.
They have fascinating stories.
Some of them are immigrants, some of them are minorities, and they were deeply offended
by critical race theory or by the school's handling of transgender policies.
And many of them were deeply offended by the COVID policies and continue to be deeply offended
by the COVID policies.
And a lot of them have never been involved in politics before, never thought they would
be involved in politics before, as one of the parents tells us.
We'd much rather be mowing the lawn, barbecuing than babysitting educators and babysitting
elected officials.
And so it's a really fascinating glimpse at something that is happening all over the
country that in fact the people in Loudon are hearing from people in Wisconsin, they're
hearing from people in other states saying they were inspired by Loudon County.
So we wanted to give you a little taste of what they told us.
Because we think that it has larger relevance.
We think it has broader relevance.
We think it's really happening around the country in very parallel situations.
But these particular parents inspired a lot of that.
And what they have to say about their backgrounds and their children and their school system
can be helpful to people and will just be plainly very compelling to people around the country.
So please enjoy, meet the parents, how the moms and dads of Loudon County took back Virginia.
And of course don't forget that you can stream the full-length documentary anywhere
on our social media, YouTube, Facebook, Rumble, even on our Twitter.
If you're looking for some family-friendly entertainment in these long and wonderful
days between Christmas and New Year's, we highly recommend you check Meet the Parents
out.
It's a great family-friendly option for everybody to watch together.
So without further ado, please enjoy the special audio edition of Meet the Parents.
That's John Tigas.
John is a local activist who's been hosting informal potluck strategy sessions for other
Loudon County parents in a small room in the basement of his rustic, rural barn, which
he operates as a wedding venue.
While for homemade chili and some cold beer, a scrappy group of parents turned activists
gathered in the basement of John's barn on a warm Thursday evening just 12 days before
Glenn Yunken's upset victory in the Virginia gubernatorial election.
The parents were bullish with Loudon County schools at the forefront, education was the
top issue, and Yunken was sounding all the right notes, but their mission that evening
was almost simpler.
They were going to take back the schools.
A team of Federalist reporters, some with deep local ties in Loudon County, made the
drive out to John's barn, where the parents agreed to be interviewed about their efforts.
Less than two weeks later, Blue Virginia would vote red.
Parents convened at John's barn were activated by a mixture of COVID lockdown policies,
critical race theory, and opposition to radical transgender ideology that had been
embraced by the school board.
Most never saw themselves becoming activists, but that changed very quickly.
Meet the parents of Loudon County because they're probably like the parents around you, too.
So how long have you lived in Loudon County?
About 25 years.
I have been here since 1982.
We were first in Alexandria.
They moved us to Loudon County about three and a half years ago.
Almost 23 years here in Loudon.
My husband was injured in Afghanistan.
He's a Special Operations Green Braid.
He medically retired in 2020.
We moved here the year prior because we knew that that was in process, and it was somewhere
where we wanted to raise our children, particularly because we thought the school system was going
to be amazing here.
What brought you to Loudon?
Well, after you want the whole story or you want to...
So after grad school, I tried to make my way south, and never made it past Virginia.
Got married here.
I was so young.
I mean, these roads were only two lanes back then, and there was a significant boom in...
I remember in high school when the malls were...
There was talk about the blueprint of the mall that was going to be put in, so Loudon County
was going to be put on the map.
I remember there was a point in time where Leesburg was the edge of the earth.
I was working in the county, for the county, and it was time to just bite the bullet and
buy a house and come out to Loudon because it just...
I thought it was a great place.
It was kind of like the frontier for us, at least.
Do you have family in the schools or kids in the schools?
Yeah, I have a daughter that's in 11th grade and a wife that's a teacher.
I've got two kids that are in northern Virginia schools.
They're grandkids.
I have six sons.
I've got two kids.
I've got a 13-year-old that goes to Little School in the county, and then I also have
a nine-year-old that's a special needs child that also goes to school in the county.
Is this the first political involvement that you've had?
Yes.
You moved here five years ago.
Is this the first time you've been thinking about it?
Yes, it is.
And that's unfortunate.
I feel bad about making this the first, but at least I'm doing this.
And I'll go from here.
I've never been involved in politics up until three years ago.
Did you go to rallies of a before-like Tea Party kind of things, or was this your first
entrance into activism in politics?
Did you say Tea Party?
Yeah.
Yeah, I was an Obama voter.
I was just following politics, but not politically active.
I walked a very middle line, and I voted on what I thought was good about the person,
and I didn't really look in depth at what these people were doing and how it affected
me.
The campaigning worked on me, and now I realize the depth of what is happening and how these
things play out long term, and how they actually affect our communities, especially
those urban communities that I grew up in, and how just dysfunctional they are.
It has really moved me over more to the conservative side, and I'll never be silent again.
I am an engineer by education.
I am a stay-at-home mom, and I homeschool my son.
You know, it's funny I see all this chatter online from the opposition out here.
You and prior never voted in a school board election.
Like, that's true.
I don't hide that.
That's part of the problem.
Like, we all have to point the finger at ourselves for not getting involved earlier.
I started a group called Army of Parents.
I spend at least three to four days a week in this fight.
I don't live in this county.
I don't have a child in the public schools.
I have no dog in this fight, but I will not stay home.
Well, I first got involved because of the kids being out of school, and I was fighting
for the kids to go back to school five days a week.
My children were not in Loudoun County Public School at the time.
I had seen them biting on the wall.
I took them out of school.
Never saw myself in politics at all.
This sort of came upon me as a result of what's going on with the schools and everything.
Mostly critical race theory was kind of what got me going.
Somebody asked me to take over the Loudoun County Republican Women's Club.
So I became the president, and we grew from 25 this year to over 450.
The first thing that I saw was an article last summer that was talking about using teaching
tolerance materials in Loudoun County Public Schools.
And, you know, teaching tolerance is an arm of the Southern Poverty Law Center.
I've worked in politics long enough to know that nonprofits are not necessarily charitable
institutions.
And having worked in the Department of Justice, I know all about the Southern Poverty Law
Center.
So I got interested in what actually was going on in Loudoun County Public Schools.
I ended up going to Republican meetings, and I joined the Loudoun County Republican Women's
Club.
There are a few of us men in there.
Just to kind of see what's going on out there, just to see some like-minded folks.
I've a proponent of watching current affairs and current events and stuff like that, and
there's certain terminology and buzzwords and things that just weren't lining up and
to see them consecutively in a row one after another just kind of set off red flags.
And so I began watching it more closely.
It started with a mass mandate, then it went on from there to critical race theory, and
then on from there to all of the rest of the things that the school board has been doing
to take over and cause closed meetings instead of open meetings.
They've done everything they can to try to stifle us.
We weren't even aware of any of this critical race theory, any of this transgender push,
any of these mandates.
We were just wanting in-person learning.
I was born in Iran, and their writing was on the wall for me when I saw what was happening.
The manipulation, the contradictions, the back and forth, the masks work, they don't work.
It felt like every time they contradicted themselves, it was to create an environment
where everyone was pinned up against each other.
So they wanted neighbors against neighbors.
I even asked my son, I'm like, do you guys see racism here?
And he goes, Mom, on the football team, we're just on the line.
We don't care what color the kid next to us is, we just care that he holds the line.
So that spoke volumes that these children who are innocent don't see color the way adults
I love the people in my neighborhood.
I love that my children have friends who are from all walks of life, all colors, all ages, all religions.
This is a wonderful county.
And what has happened over the past two years, it really, really saddens me.
It makes me very, very upset, and it makes me fearful for our kids and the future.
A year ago at this time, people weren't watching critical race theory.
I was, I started my organization a little over a year ago.
When everybody was focused on the lockdown and kids being out of school and everything like that,
my son graduated high school this year and my daughter was in.
And I wasn't going to win a fight on, are you going to get back in school or not?
And I could see the trail of destruction starting to come.
I saw it in the spring of 2020.
What is critical race theory and is it actually being taught to students here in Loudoun County
and around the country who aren't in college but are children?
Yeah, so I can ask that question a lot.
And I'm going to just define it the way that Loudoun County public schools consultants define it,
which is that Western liberalism, meritocracy, and equal opportunity perpetuate systemic racism.
And now is critical race theory taught?
No, it's not taught like it's physics or chemistry, but it's embedded in the systems of how things are
taught. It works its way into the teacher trainings.
Teachers eventually teach our children and they utilize these resources and these concepts in
their lesson plan. I wrote this article and said, there's some strange stuff here going on.
It looks like they're using our kids as guinea pigs. And I kind of thought that was the end of it.
It was a no. No, it was definitely not the end of it.
Yeah, you want me to just look like right there?
I'm not a Loudoun County resident. What I do is work with grassroots teens all across the state
and just support parents like the ones here in Loudoun County,
equip them when they are doing things like going before a school board and testifying or
want to have a community rally. We stand behind them and offer free resources for that.
I also think Loudoun was piling on. I mean, you had parents already concerned about
lack of transparency with the sex education issue. Then they're piling on with the critical
race theory stuff. Then they'd write right in the middle of all that critical race theory
controversy. They were trying to push through this transgender ideology, this radical policy,
which it was coming from the state level, but they also had their own version of the policy,
which was pretty radical, basically promoting transgender ideology into every component of
school life. That's coming on right after the critical race theory that parents were already
upset about. It is a huge pile on effect. I do think maybe Loudoun was a little bit, or a lot,
arrogant, and not realizing what was simmering that is now coming to the surface with the
parents pushing back on office. I think what you're seeing here today or what's going on right now
is really something that's been simmering for quite a while. That is these parents continuing to feel
like they have this pattern of gross disrespect from the school board, a lack of transparency,
and almost this paternalistic treatment. That's all escalated within the last two years, but I
think it's really been a process that has been years in the making. One of the school board members,
Beth Bartz, who recently resigned, started to ask her constituents in a secret Facebook group
to find out who parents were that were going to the school board meetings. A bunch of parents
had been basically plotted against in this private Facebook group that included six school board
members, the Commonwealth's attorney out here, and a member of the board of supervisors. So Beth
Bartz went on Facebook, said poor me, the school board, you know, the parents are not being very
nice. And these men and women, they listed probably 40 to 50 of us, our first and last name, three
pictures of me, who are married to, where my son goes to high school. They called me at disgusting,
they called me a racist, they said they were going to come to my neighborhood with a megaphone and
call us racist. They said that we were going to, they were going to mail postcards to our homes.
This has all started from a school board elected official. There's a school board member by the
name of Beth Bartz to put out a call to action to come after me, my family, my organization,
my employer, my kids. You know, prior, I think as somebody else you talked to, there's another
parameter to in a room that, that were also on the list. And my organization was specifically
named, it was specifically named in that in Mitch McConnell's letter to
A.G. Garland just last week. So, and then sued some death threats. And then recently within the
past month, somebody went after my job, but I still stand. You know, I was put on the list by
people that I knew for my federalist article. And also for speaking up at a single school board
meeting about first amendment rights of students and teachers. And you know, at that point, I said,
listen, this is, this is cancel culture brought to the neighborhood level, brought to the community
level. And you know, people have to speak out. A lot of my club members would send me screenshots
or videos of things that they uncovered. So during COVID, I would be looming over my youngest son's
Chromebook, making sure he's doing his homework correctly. And I don't know if you recall that
video that went viral of the Freedom High School student that was being pressured by the teacher
to look at what is race. And it was a picture of a white girl and a black girl. And the kid is
like, I just see two people chilling. And the teacher bullied him into saying what is race. And
the kids like, if I give into this, then we're, aren't we giving into the separation by race?
So the kid was very smart. My member, club member sent it to me. I, we re-edited it so the children's
neighbors were taken out and it went viral. And we realized that other parents could respond and
appreciate this. My son was shown a video, which I mean, to kind of sum it up, it had a young
black girl and a young white girl. And the video started off with statements about racism and
discrimination. And it was disturbing because all the people that were being shown were white.
So a white police officer, a white doctor, a white business person, a white nurse, and then as you
go through the video, it goes on to say that, you know, the little black girl may have gone to
school with the little white girl, but she's not going to get a job or she's not going to get the
same amount of money or she's not going to have the same opportunities. And that was sort of what
kind of was a line in the sand for me. That my son was, it was from Brain Pop and it was part
of the material that they used to teach kids and it was disturbing to see that. My son doesn't need
to see that. So we became organized and we parents would show up to the school board. You'll recall
sometimes we had these signs with printed words. We found sexually explicit books. I mean, my club
was instrumental in giving us the anonymous information. We protected teachers. We said send
us this culturally responsive training that they're pushing and they would send us all this stuff.
So I got involved not because I'm president of this large Republican women's club, but because
I'm a mom and they went after us and tried to blacklist us. Some of the most hurtful things to
me are when people slam the country. Kids coming out of college that have utilized the capitalist
system and the freedoms of America to be able to graduate from college and say that America is
the worst place on the globe. Just two years ago, I couldn't tell you who our school board members
were. I don't think anybody around here could, mostly across the country. Now I can tell you
how much they weigh, right? Because we're that in tune and I don't mean that literally because
I don't get any back there. But that's how in tune we are with what's going on with this,
with in our communities. We used to be able to be in the room and then every time we go,
there's a different procedure. It's either starts at four, it starts at five or it starts at six
30. We never know. We could be outside in the rain, let in virtual speak first,
and then the in-person have to wait. We used to have 30 seconds. Now it's a minute.
Nope, go back to 30 seconds. Then you have to stand on little numbers. They now wand us. They
take a security wand and check us in before we go in. The power that they pretend to have
is ridiculous because if you've never done this before, it's very intimidating. I started going to
school board meetings. I started trying to understand what's going on in the schools.
And then I did some research on critical race theory. So being from an academic background,
you know, like just engineering, I started reading some books and I read a book from one of the
more prominent authors on critical research just to understand it so that I'm knowledgeable about
what I'm criticizing. It did not like what I saw at all. It basically is a reincarnation
of racism. We already lived that through American history. We don't need to recycle it and bring
it back. I was the woman who stood up on the chair at the June 22nd board meeting and saying
the stars bangled down her and my terrible horrible voice. But I felt like it was needed because we
needed to bring ourselves together as a group. What really compelled me was the divisiveness
that has occurred in our community. And it made me really sad. My children are growing up in here,
parents, all parents in this community. Their children are going to grow up here. And we cannot
have this divisiveness. And when the board walked out of the room, I could feel an energy bubbling
up that wasn't good. And I just thought we're one community. We're loud in county and we're all
Americans. And what better way to bring us all together than with the star spangled banner.
So I climbed up on the chair, pulled up another girlfriend, and I just started singing. And a
girlfriend across from me, she stood up on the chair. And we sang the star spangled banner together.
And the entire room erupted in the star spangled banner. And it did. Because for one moment,
we were all Americans. We weren't on this side of the issue or that side of the issue. We were one.
And I think that's something that we're forgetting as a community is that if we allow this division
to come between us as parents, it will seep into our children. And that's evidence by
the increase in violence that we're seeing in the schools. So we need to come together.
We need to be able to talk about what we have in common rather than what we don't in order to
find a solution. We made a recall effort happen. We had one board member quit before her recall
because she saw the recall numbers. And she's out. So they hear it. We're making a difference.
Parents are starting to get really involved. And they're starting to say no more. And when your
children are being hurt in school, we have to say what can we do? I think it's this phenomenon
of seeing one parent stand up at a school board meeting and read a book out loud, or, you know,
just one parent and then others started coming along. So it really was that spark of courage that
really was ignited a fire here.
I'll be honest, you don't piss off a Cuban mom. My parents escaped from communist Cuba. So they
taught me to appreciate the freedoms that we have here, smaller government, less restrictions. This
kind of attitude reminded my parents of what happened to them. I grew up poor, Hispanic, in the Bronx,
in New York City. Didn't have any problems succeeding. Nobody held me back. When I was growing up,
my mom said, when are you going to college? Not if you're going to college. When you go to college.
We didn't have money for school, student loans, and grants and things like that. But I never felt
that anybody was going to hold me back from doing what I wanted to do. And I want the same for my
kids and all kids, because I think it's it's reprehensible to tell kids that they're not going to make it
at that young age. The fact that I had my freedom once taken away from me
makes me feel as if I was made for this. This is why I've endured what I've endured.
Now in Loudon County, there's probably not a lot of people who have the same story that you have
growing up poor and Hispanic in the Bronx. But there's a lot of these folks are pushing the
the critical race theory and the you've got no shot and you you won't be able to get a job if
you're not this bracket or that bracket. A lot of the folks who are pushing this off were just
white traditional American liberals. Have you been targeted for that? What's the reaction
that has been from them? Is someone speaking out? I haven't had any harassment or threats or
targeting or anything. And I think you have to take a step back from the label and the branding of
critical race theory. Let's dissect it a little bit. The premise is it has parallels with Marxism
because Marxism was a class based system and this is now a race based system. But the parallels are
clear. They're not you don't even need to be an academic or or a historian to see how it ties
together. And and what's disturbing is that Marxism doesn't work. Well rebranding it with race
certainly doesn't work. You can put as much lipstick on a pig as you want. It's still a pig.
And have a very big problem with impressionable youths being taught that whatever color you are
is going to affect how people look at you talk to you and your successes. That is one step forward
18 steps backward. That is going back to slavery. That's going back to discrimination. That's going
back to all sorts of things. I think more Republicans are stepping forward. I think more
independents are realizing they need to support Republican candidates. And I really think a lot
of soft Democrats have woken up. Many of my club members I can call I can count at least 10 that
have left the Democrat party that are now Republicans. So I think there's been a big shift. I don't
really even talk about politics because where where I come from meaning this world pack is I
don't care. Right. We have kids. There's going to be Republicans and Democrats and independents
and that have kids in the school systems. And we're all facing the same problem. So I don't
care where they come from. What I care about is their sentiment. They're discussed. Their
disbelief and what is going on. I've seen black parents, Hispanic parents, Indian parents, white
parents, just a lot of people that are just outraged. What I'm doing with Patriot pubs is
I'm trying to put a national effort together to go to all these other places where people
want to find someone they can talk with. They can't talk with their friends. They can't talk
with their people at work because they're on a different side of things. But they they're exploding
the desire to say I need to talk to a friend. And what we want to do is we want to go out. And
first goal is to have 10 pubs, Patriot pubs in each state. So it's not that many when you consider
the states and when you consider the people who are there, they want to join. We're getting calls
from Nebraska. We're getting calls from all over the country saying what can we do? How can we do this?
This was a big wake up call for a lot of parents because we took for granted our local elected
officials and their role and even the voting process. So this was a big wake up call. This was a big
like we can mobilize and we can be organized to say no that the government overreach that they're
you know doing to us is not right. Especially don't piss off a mother. Like these are our children.
And we don't co-parent with the government. We don't co-parent with this school board.
And they have been nothing short of ignoring us, dismissing us. We've asked for a town hall.
They refuse to be transparent. So there are quite a few lawsuits and I'm actually in a lawsuit
against them with Liberty Justice Center. Well if it can happen here it can happen anywhere.
And as you've said people are tired of it and there are 70 million people across the country who
feel like they haven't been heard. They weren't heard in the last election and they want to be
heard now and there are people that are talking and trying to find a way to get together. The
losers in all of this are people that cannot get out of the public education system. So it's the
very people that the politicians say they're working for that are losing. Are you optimistic?
Yeah it's a long fight and there's there's not a singular fight. There's multiple tracks.
Right there's the school board. There's a board of supervisors. There's content. There's
a lot of different things. But I'm confident we're going to win in different areas.
I'm hearing a lot from other people. You know first of all a lot of people are inspired by
what's happening in Loudoun County. You know I remember reading I don't know if it was a reporter
that told me or a story but they asked somebody in Wisconsin a question about you know why are you
doing what you're doing and they said it's a Loudoun County. And you know I've gotten tons of emails
over the past seven months. How can we do hear what you're doing there? What is happening in Loudoun
is having a ripple effect across the state because other parents are seeing oh these parents are
standing up against a huge well-funded school board considered the epicenter of liberalism
and they're making a difference. Oh maybe we can do you know we can do that too. Well I believe
COVID was one of the best things that could have happened to the next generation because it forced
us to shut down. It forced us to look at our families and look at our kids and pay attention
to our school system and what they're teaching them. Bringing them home and allowing us to listen
to what they're what's actually being taught. What have you taken away from seeing that happen
that you hope that parents in every county across the country where some version of this
many-headed beast is going to rear its head. What's the one thing that you would tell them today about
something they need to know? I think it would be remember why this country was founded. Remember
why we're here. A government I think it's of buy and for the people. The government gets
his power from us. I'll tell you when I first started I was scared I was scared that people were
going to call me names or talk about me behind my back but it really doesn't matter because you're
doing if you believe that you are doing the right thing for your community and your children
and your family then you have to just stand up and be brave. What's the worst thing that can happen?
Somebody calls you a name, you lose your job. That's hard. I understand that but at some point you have
to be able to make sacrifices for doing the right thing and I truly believe that what we're doing
is not partisan. It's parents in. It's not left. It's not right. It's right or wrong. I don't believe
that what's happening right now with Loudoun County's Organic. I think this is all intentional
because it doesn't make sense that Little Loudoun is dealing with the same thing as the counties in
Michigan. This isn't every county that matters. If we want to see a true freedom revolution in
America which we need it is not going to happen top down. It is only going to happen with local
engagement over the long term in communities. This school board has single handedly almost
brought down a party. We're at 18 percent nationwide of homeschoolers now. I mean that's close to 20
percent nationwide. That's huge. We're taking our children back. We're taking the next generation
back. We're taking our country back. What I have to say to the left right now if you think you're safe
you're deadly mistaken. We're in the front line. Once they come through us they're coming for you
just because you think you're saying everything that the government agrees with doesn't mean that
you're going to be free. Doesn't mean that you're going to get to keep your rights. I tell people
over and over again I much rather would be at home you know watching TV cutting the grass,
watching movies, just being with my family instead of having to do this and having to babysit
politicians that are not doing what they're supposed to be doing. I was a very middle of the road
voter. I wouldn't ascribe to one party or the other. This is really all of this corruption has
driven me more to the conservative side because I want to be free and I want to make informed choices.
One local elected official points firmly to the dawn of covid lockdowns as the dawn of the movement,
the parent led movement to retake Loudon County.
My name is Joel Groovy. I'm the executive director of homeschool legal defense association
action and I am a member of the town council for the town of person. You have to start with March
2020. March 2020 there was a two-week window when across the nation the school is closed.
Okay starting I think it was March 19th. You would not believe how many times I have someone
talk to me with it like so the final straw was when my kid was sitting in the dining room table
listening to this and then they heard a thing and it varies a lot what the thing is. And they're
like I'm sorry what and there's been sort of a story where like the parents head
descends upside down over the camera as they're kind of looking over the they're like I'm sorry
what did you say and and the teachers were legitimate. They was talking on twitter and
Facebook and much different things and people are going this is not okay parents cannot be in
the classroom this is horrible. And the parents were like oh heck yes I can be in my kid's classroom.
They're my kids not yours. In a sense covid shut down public input to things but it let them see
the out working at the end. And so a series of policies were passed that were found to be
